Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, new nanopatterning methods will be researched for manufacturing based on two self-assembly model systems: (1) block copolymers; and (2) collapsing nanopillars. For both of these technologies, analytical models will be developed explaining the interaction between topographic templates the self-assembling action of the system. Along with the analytical model, numerical simulation will be used to simulate the 3-D structures. A conceptual framework for pattern design based on computation and digital logic will then be developed. In the particular case of block copolymers, central to the technological development will be the implementation of localized annealing methods. In the case of collapsing nanopillars, processing methods for inducing localized and directed collapse will be developed. Based on the analytical model, numerical simulation, the new experimental methods, and the computational framework, a new approach for generating complex nanopatterns will be demonstrated using both of these approaches.

As the result of this work, new nanomanufacturing methods that can fabricate complex nanopatterns with throughput higher than that of conventional lithographic methods will be developed. The primary goal of this study is controlling the self-assembly process based on the understanding of the force or interaction governing the self-assembly process of two model systems. The control may include fabricating complex nanopatterns such as bends, jogs, or T-junctions that can be used for integrated circuit fabrication or for fabrication of large-scale nanopatterns for new applications in photonics, energy harvesting, and electronics. As a result of the control of self-assembly to be achieved in this study, the capabilities of nanomanufacturing methods will be expanded, while their costs are reduced.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Self-assembly is a process in which disorganized individual components in a system interact with each other to form an ordered pattern. There are various types of materials that can be self-assembled, such as nanoparticles, proteins, and DNAs. Since self-assembly can be performed on such nanoscale components, it is utilized in nanotechnology to fabricate complex well-ordered patterns which are difficult to create by conventional tools. In this project, we focused on two different self-assembly systems: (1) capillary force-induced paired collapse of nanoscale wall structures; and (2) block copolymers (BCPs).

Capillary force-induced collapse is a common phenomenon in nature. When a liquid meniscus is formed on a patterned surface, capillary force is applied at the interface between liquid and air around the nanostructures. As the meniscus moves during liquid evaporation, asymmetric capillary force induces collapse of the nanostructures and the nanostructures are self-assembled into complex hierarchical patterns. This phenomenon is especially relevant to nanotechnology due to the drying processes involved in the fabrication steps.

In this work, we developed a method to control the meniscus movement and collapsing order of nanoscale wall structures. Without such meniscus movement control, the collapsing order and collapsing direction of the walls were random. However, by using a spin drying process to control the meniscus movement, we demonstrated pairwise collapse of the walls. Therefore, an even number of walls were fully paired whereas an odd number of walls resulted in one unpaired final wall after the spin drying process. By controlling the pairing of the final wall by changing the number of walls in an array, we built a proof-of-concept logic gate.

A BCP is composed of two different polymer blocks that are covalently bonded together in the middle. BCPs can microphase separate into different morphologies such as spheres, cylinders, gyroids, and lamellae depending on what polymer blocks constitute the BCP. Because BCPs self-assemble in molecular level, sub-10-nm patterns can be easily fabricated.

In this work, we used a cylinder forming BCP and studied the effect of confinement on the resulting morphology. Without a template to guide the direction of self-assembly, BCPs naturally formed patterns with poor long range order. When BCPs were confined inside a polygonal template such as circular or hexagonal holes, they formed concentric rings. However, when they were confined inside a square confinement, they formed ladder-shaped structures instead of concentric rings due to the stress caused by the 90° bending angle. T-junctions and 90° bends formed inside the ladder-shaped structures are relevant to integrated circuit layout fabrication. Furthermore, alignment orientation of the ladder-shaped structures were controlled by (1) changing the confinement geometry and (2) making an opening around the confinement. Using the square confinement as components, we developed a new pattern generation technique.

This work was performed by two graduate students. The graduate students participated as volunteers in Nano-Observatory day of the Cambridge Science Festival which was hosted as part of the project. The students showed MIT’s Scanning-Electron-Beam Lithography Facility (SEBL) to the visitors (K-12 students and parents). As a result, this research has had direct educational impact on society.


Last Modified: 12/11/2015
Modified by: Karl Berggren
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Self-assembly is a process in which disorganized individual components in a system interact with each other to form an ordered pattern. There are various types of materials that can be self-assembled, such as nanoparticles, proteins, and DNAs. Since self-assembly can be performed on such nanoscale components, it is utilized in nanotechnology to fabricate complex well-ordered patterns which are difficult to create by conventional tools. In this project, we focused on two different self-assembly systems: (1) capillary force-induced paired collapse of nanoscale wall structures; and (2) block copolymers (BCPs). When a liquid meniscus is formed on a patterned surface, capillary force is applied at the interface between liquid and air around the nanostructures. As the meniscus moves during liquid evaporation, asymmetric capillary force induces collapse of the nanostructures and the nanostructures are self-assembled into complex hierarchical patterns. Using the square confinement as components, we developed a new pattern generation technique. This work was performed by two graduate students.
